ID performance consistently improves with LYP.
Tab.Â 1 shows that across all model architectures the top scores are achieved using LYP.
For instance, we see improvements in ğ’â€‹@ğ’@\mathcal{C}@1% over both MaxProb (A+B) and Selector (B) with OFA-Large of 16.61% and 2.06%, respectively.
Likewise, Î¦100subscriptÎ¦100\Phi_{100} increases with LYP by 12.49 and 1.20 over MaxProb (A+B) and Selector (B), respectively, for OFA-Large.
The improvements are sustained at higher risk levels and lower costs (e.g., +0.63% ğ’â€‹@ğ’@\mathcal{C}@10% for Selector with LYP for CLIP-ViL compared to Selector trained on held-out data).
These observations hold across each model we experiment with on ID data.
Lastly, we see that all Selector models outperform all MaxProb models on every metric, just as in [67].

For our OOD evaluations, we build mixed datasets comprised of 10%, 33%, 50%, and 66% OOD examples.
All mixtures contain 5K examples from AdVQA as OOD examples, and the rest are randomly sampled from the ID VQA v2 test split.
We report the results on the 10% OOD mixture in Tab.Â 2.
More details, results (e.g., on other mixtures), and qualitative examples are in the appendix.

LYP maintains improvements over other methods in the 90%/10% setting.
Similar to the pure ID setting, LYP continues to outperform other methods on the 90%/10% mixed setting as shown in Tab.Â 2.
Although, we see decreases in all metrics across each of the different methods, demonstrating the challenge of this task even with just 10% OOD data.

OOD detection features do not necessarily help.
Inspired byÂ [15], we train Selector with out-of-distribution detection scores computed with KNNÂ [57] or SSDÂ [52] as added features.
We find that these features do not bring significant improvements to our evaluation metrics (Tab.Â 3).
More details about those experiments can be found in the appendix.
has the details of the OOD Detection features, which we use in the experiments in Table 3 of the main paper.

To compute those metrics, we use the representations from the encoder of OFA.

references:
Augmenting Selector training with known OOD data also does not improve.
As discussed in Sec.Â 3.3, we also try training Selector on the B set, along with some known OOD datasets similar to [32].
This may help learn to discard hard examples which are very far from its training distribution.
For this experiment, we use the training sets of OK-VQAÂ [45], which has the same image distribution but a different question distribution, and of VizWizÂ [23], which has both image and question distribution shifts compared to VQA v2.
We see in Tab.Â 4 that this method is not very successful at improving selective prediciton in this OOD evaluation setting.
Contrary to the findings ofÂ [32] for text-only question answering, on the Selective VQA task, adding this known OOD data during training decreases the performance of our Selector on unknown OOD data at test time.
Overall, it appears that more traditional approaches for handling OOD examples may have difficulty generalizing to this multimodal setting.

references:
Different numbers of splits/peers for LYP.
We ablate the number of splits/peer models Nğ‘N of the training data ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} with OFA-Base.
Ideally, the peer models in LYP should have predictions and failure modes similar to the full model, which suggests that more peer models may be better (i.e., each peer model is trained on more data).
We see in Tab.Â 5 that for OFA-Base the number of peers has a small impact on the final results.
However, we also find that the difference in accuracy of OFA-Base fine-tuned on 50% vs 100% of the training data is small (74.03% vs 75.18%).
Therefore, the difference in signal from the labels of 2 vs 10 peers may be similar.
For VQA models with less pre-training, this difference may be greater and more models may be needed.
This suggests that the training requirements for LYP can be reduced while maintaining strong performance for large pre-trained models.

Effect of training data size.
We show in Tab.Â 6 that the amount of data used for the Selector training is an important factor for its performance.
Note that the Train B set, used by Â [67] to train their selector, has 86K examples, which is âˆ¼similar-to\sim15% of the full Train A+B.
The additional data, labeled with LYP, helps Selector generalize better to test examples.

references: To further understand the usefulness of additional OOD data for Selector training in our multimodal setting as suggested in [32] for text-only NLP tasks, we provide an additional ablation: In Tab.Â 8 for the ID/OOD training setup, we train only on the B set + the OK-VQA training set, i.e. without VizWiz data (third line in each section of the table). The OK-VQA is more similar to AdVQA compared to VizWiz. However, we observe similar results compared to using both OOD datasets: Additional Known OOD does not consistently improve the results over the baseline (i.e. most identical to the selector setup in [67]), especially for low risk, the model with OK-VQA does not perform well. Alternative use of such known OOD data in the multimodal setting is out of scope for this work, but it is an interesting avenue for future work to study how to potentially better exploit such data.

A3.T9.caption: Table 9: Comparison of joint and staged training of OFA-Base and Selector. FT indicates that Selector is further fine-tuned after OFA-Base converges on the VQA training objective. All models are trained on A+B.
A3.T9.table:
Training Acc ğ’â€‹@ğ’@\mathcal{C}@1% ğ’â€‹@ğ’@\mathcal{C}@5% ğ’â€‹@ğ’@\mathcal{C}@10% AUC
ID (100% VQA v2)
joint 75.08 16.04 42.78 65.91 8.11
joint+FT 75.08 24.42 50.01 69.20 7.21
staged 75.18 26.64 50.80 69.56 7.10
90% VQA v2, 10% AdVQA
joint 71.97 10.74 34.61 53.81 10.12

staged 72.00 19.72 42.70 60.84 8.90
references:
The results in Tab.Â 9 illustrate that joint training decreases the overall performance of the Selector.
All metrics yield worse performance with joint training alone, though the gap shrinks when freezing the VQA model and continuing to fine-tune Selector.
This is despite the fact that the overall VQA accuracy remains roughly the same with or without joint training.
We conjecture that the reason for this may be that joint training creates a somewhat non-stationary optimization problem for Selector.
Specifically, the VQA modelâ€™s representations and VQA accuracy are changing throughout training.
This means that the statistics of the inputs and training targets for Selector (see AppendixÂ D) are changing, which may make optimizing Selector more difficult.
Other techniques may be needed in order to properly optimize the VQA model and Selector together.

Training Selector with OFA.
We report the training parameters in Tab.Â 10.
We first train the VQA model as discussed above, freeze the VQA model, and then train Selector on top of this frozen model, followingÂ [67].
We train for a maximum number of 32 epochs and perform early-stopping on the Val split (Tab.Â 11) using the AUC metric.
We keep the dropout in the main model during the selector training, as we found this improved performance of the selector.

Training Selector with OFA.
We report the training parameters in Tab.Â 10.
We first train the VQA model as discussed above, freeze the VQA model, and then train Selector on top of this frozen model, followingÂ [67].
We train for a maximum number of 32 epochs and perform early-stopping on the Val split (Tab.Â 11) using the AUC metric.

We follow [67] and use the splits provided in the official implementation.
We detail the splits again in Tab.Â 11.
Note, in our work we repurpose the â€œDevâ€ set from [67] for our Train B split.
No images (or question-answer annotations) are shared between splits.

In our work, we create mixtures of ID/OOD examples for our evaluations.
To form our mixtures, we first discard all AdVQA images that overlap with the A+B train set.
This leaves 5,008 AdVQA examples.
For each setting, we randomly sample examples from the ID Test split (Tab.Â 11) to create the desired OOD proportion: 45K for 10% OOD, 10K for 33% OOD, 5K for 50% OOD and 2.5K for 66% OOD.

We also see that our LYP method is very efficient to improve the results over the regular Selector model setup from [67].

We show experiments for our models and LYP on the visual entailment dataset SNLI-VEÂ [70] in Tab.Â 14. Given an image premise, and a text hypothesis, the model has to return one of the three possible outputs: entailment, neutral, or contradiction. We run the experiments on OFA-Base, and use the same setup as the original OFA paper [66], except that we do not use the textual premise to make it comparable to previous works.

references:
In Tabs.Â 15, 16, 17, 18 andÂ 19, we present the results for our experiments on the all OOD mixtures of VQA v2 and AdVQAÂ [54].
While we on average see that the Selector models and Selector + LYP perform better than the corresponding baselines models out-of-the-box (MaxProb), all models degrade dramatically if there is a high percentage of OOD data in the test mixture, especially for low risk (ğ’â€‹@ğ’@\mathcal{C}@1%) or high cost of error (Î¦100subscriptÎ¦100\Phi_{100}).
Especially if we look at the realistic scenario where the threshold is chosen on the validation set and used at test time (as for Î¦100subscriptÎ¦100\Phi_{100}), we notice that the scores of all methods drop below 0 with 33.3% or more OOD data.
This can be seen in the last column of Tabs.Â 17, 18 andÂ 19.
These results demonstrate that these thresholds can be overconfident on OOD examples, which leads to poor abstention decisions such that the cost of the modelsâ€™ incorrect outputs outweighs the gains of the correct ones.
Future work is needed to improve such OOD generalization and recognizing samples that cannot reliably be answered in this challenging setup, which this work provides a new and interesting test setup for.

We propose a potential mitigation strategy for such cases.
First, we use the VQA model trained only on the A subset, instead of the one trained on the full A+B like in LYP.
Then, we train a Selector on the full A+B data, using the following strategy: we use LYP only on the A subset and use the modelâ€™s own labels on the B subset.
This allows the Selector to be trained partly on some data that was unseen during the VQA modelâ€™s training, with real confidence labels.
This potentially helps the selector capture the modelâ€™s real uncertainty.
We call this strategy LYP-A Self-B and report it in all Tabs.Â 15, 16, 17, 18 andÂ 19.

references:
In Tabs.Â 15, 16, 17, 18 andÂ 19, we present the results for our experiments on the all OOD mixtures of VQA v2 and AdVQAÂ [54].
While we on average see that the Selector models and Selector + LYP perform better than the corresponding baselines models out-of-the-box (MaxProb), all models degrade dramatically if there is a high percentage of OOD data in the test mixture, especially for low risk (ğ’â€‹@ğ’@\mathcal{C}@1%) or high cost of error (Î¦100subscriptÎ¦100\Phi_{100}).
Especially if we look at the realistic scenario where the threshold is chosen on the validation set and used at test time (as for Î¦100subscriptÎ¦100\Phi_{100}), we notice that the scores of all methods drop below 0 with 33.3% or more OOD data.
This can be seen in the last column of Tabs.Â 17, 18 andÂ 19.
These results demonstrate that these thresholds can be overconfident on OOD examples, which leads to poor abstention decisions such that the cost of the modelsâ€™ incorrect outputs outweighs the gains of the correct ones.
Future work is needed to improve such OOD generalization and recognizing samples that cannot reliably be answered in this challenging setup, which this work provides a new and interesting test setup for.

We propose a potential mitigation strategy for such cases.
First, we use the VQA model trained only on the A subset, instead of the one trained on the full A+B like in LYP.
Then, we train a Selector on the full A+B data, using the following strategy: we use LYP only on the A subset and use the modelâ€™s own labels on the B subset.
This allows the Selector to be trained partly on some data that was unseen during the VQA modelâ€™s training, with real confidence labels.
This potentially helps the selector capture the modelâ€™s real uncertainty.
We call this strategy LYP-A Self-B and report it in all Tabs.Â 15, 16, 17, 18 andÂ 19.
